Posts.Title: Port's in, making progress! SunshineSmiles LoriFL

Posts.Content: 30something wrote: Hi All I haven't posted or been on these boards for some time... I know I gained a lot of strength and wisdom from everyone on these boards when I was navigating my way through the breast cancer journey when I was first diagnosed. Life was moving beyond breast cancer (well I thought it was..) I'd nearly hit 3 years post diagnosis last week (same week I was rediagnosed). I found out last week I have 3 spots on my lungs, and one on a lymph node behind my sternum.I had some scans, as we wanted to try and start a family and my oncologist was encouraging and supportive of this, it was not what we were hoping for (an understatement!). My breast suregon said the "spots" are small, just able to be picked up on PET scan. I will be seeing my Oncologist Thurs to discuss treatment options. I was triple negative first time. This is a grey area given I am feeling really well and had it not been for some elected scans due to wanting to start a family, we don't know how long it would have been before symptoms presented. For now, just trying to focus on the moment. Somewhere, somehow I will find some strength to face this challenge... Has anyone had a similiar experience, where something has been picked up small on a scan?? It is hard for me to believe that the cancer is back as I have been feeling the best I have felt in years both physically and mentally, I think in my self I had got to a place of acceptance with it all, that the cancer might come back but I was going to do my darndest to keep living my life and achieving my dreams whatever the outcome (I am hoping perhaps this acceptance will help me to face this next hurdle and it is good that I was feeling strong in myself )... I know there will be tough days ahead.. and perhaps it will hit me further down the track? I welcome hearing from all of you. Also what should I be asking my Oncologist? Any suggested sites re information. It sounds like surgery isn't an option given more than one spot and on both lungs. Rads no, so chemo the option... although he is talking about removing a spot to check the receptors again.. This sucks, especially at the age of 35.... it has robbed me and my husband of our dreams, the doors have closed on having children and this will take me some time to get my head around as I had been living in hope, guess my hope will have to be channelled in a different direction now. Thanks for listening. Joanne Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Joing the club 30something RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2008 06:21PM 30something wrote: Any ideas? words of advice re next steps ahead?? Welcome your comments Thank you
Posts.Title: Joing the club 30something RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2008 11:09PM 30something wrote: Thank you for your posts and comments. Firstly, yes they are confirming it is mets, due to showing on CT and the exact spots on PET "lighting up" or taking up glucose. I think they are really only thinking biopsy and possible surgery to remove affected lymph node behind sternum to look at HER2 and hormone status in case that has changed. Will double check with Onc on Thursday. What else should I be asking for? Cal gal, I appreciate your openness in sharing. I have been advised given now advanced bc, pregnancy is not an option, door closed. I went through freezing embryos, seeing fertility specialist, taking lupron whilst on chemo back in 05 when I was first diagnosed. We did all we could, and after all that I got my period back and last blood tests showed normal hormone levels. DAMN! Thank you for taking the time to respond :-) I will keep you updated Joanne
Posts.Title: Joing the club 30something RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2008 02:56AM 30something wrote: Thanks for the advice... obviously different opinions... which is good to hear. I trust my Oncologist and he has a good reputation, he did say he is conservative when it comes to chemo, and his reasons sounded reasonable to me, he is discussing my case at a meeting Friday, so even though I haven't got a second opinion, I feel he is consultative and doing all he can to get others opinions... I will certainly keep the option of getting another opinion up my sleeve, guess it is one step at a time, first we need to know if the pathology has changed or not. Anyone else out there diagnosed with small spots on lungs "early"? no symptoms? I would be interested to know what steps you decided to take, especially if triple neg.  Thanks for your time and encouragement Hanging in there!
Posts.Title: Joing the club 30something RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2008 01:51AM 30something wrote: Thanks Robin, makes me feel less alone to know I aint the only one diagnosed with no symptoms etc. It is a strange feeling... your story gives me hope.  Update: Saw my Oncologist today...not much really to report..no treatment plan... seems to be taking carefully, slowly approach.. wants to share scans with lung surgeon, (or whatever their technical name is!) netx week to see what he thinks re getting access to the spots, re surgical removal to remove one or more to get tissue to biopsy, and test for hormone status, her2 etc rather than just put a needle in to biopsy.. he says still a chance it aint cancer, but if he was hedging his bets, he would be thinking cancer... (given more than one, and my history),  re treatment he said that it might be a matter of waiting and watching, as to begin treatment now when they are so small may not have a lot of benefit and just cause me to feel sick... when I feel well and don't have any symptoms... and to do a scan in 6-8 weeks to see if any changes... hard to accept that unlike last time there will be a little bit of time, just working out best way to approach it and have a plan... what have others done that have been diagnosed when no symptoms for lung mets? He said that he wants to keep the chemo options open and to begin too early may mean we run out of options quicker etc... Welcome your feedback.. HAPPY EASTER!
Posts.Title: Joing the club 30something RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2008 01:35AM 30something wrote: Sofee May I had a surgical biopsy (VATS) two weeks ago, I am not sure what type of biopsy you are having, but wanted to say that you are in my thoughts.. remember your medical team are there for you- so ask them lots of questions!
Posts.Title: ct shows lung mets-but biopsy on tuesday sofeemay faeriesong

Posts.Content: 30something wrote: I am having lung surgery next Mon, 7th April. It is going to be video assisted thoraicic surgery (vats) to get a nodule to biopsy. Just when I thought I was out of needing surgery... this happens. Hard to get my head around the thought of it again... Here's hoping it is not too painful and recovery is smooth, have bought some new pyjama's, I mean there has to be some consolation doesn't there?! Some treats! Please send me some good wishes! Thanks Joanne Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Good wishes please 30something katie11

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2008 05:18AM - edited Jun 7, 2008 05:20AM by 30something Hi LH Survivor I just wanted to say i can empathise with how you feel, I am 35 and was just about to try getting pregnant, hit the 3 yr mark after initial diagnosis (Stage 3, Triple Neg), had scans March to get "all clear" and it showed up some small mets to lungs.... I am grappling with some of the same issues as you re children, hope and goals, how can I bring children into my life...... Some days I know I have to keep planning, hoping and other days I just feel bowled over by the grief of  not having children and seeing friends getting pregnant, planning for things with their children.... it makes me feel isolated that I won't probably get to have the parenting experience.. Still  I have much to be grateful for in my life, but that doesn't ease all of the grief!:-) I am not sure re adoption... here in Australia things are a little tighter... to adopt, you would have to be cancer free for many years, if ever accepted....
Posts.Title: parenting question LongHornSurvivor LongHornSurvivor

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2008 12:45PM - edited Apr 17, 2008 12:46PM by 30something Sofee I read your post with heart felt empathy. I am 35, diagnosed at 32, officially rediagnosed with lung mets last week.  I have been on this rollercoaster ride  again for the last month, with CT scans etc.. showing a few suspicous spots. No symptoms. Take it gently, and just focus on each step, do not rush and be kind to you.... and know that somehow you will find strength, I know you can't feel it at the moment, but it is still there, burning away.  PM me if you want to share more... We all help each other. Take Care Jo
Posts.Title: Just diagnosised with metastic cancer- sofeemay hezzy

I am scared, nervous, guess it is normal with any surgery.. bring on end of next week I say! Thank you:-) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Surgery 30something anitach

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2008 12:52AM 30something wrote: Thank You! I am on the "other side", surgery went well Monday, got out of hospital yesterday, just have some pain on left side where they went in and  it hurts to cough, but compared to other surgery I have had so far it has been manageable, re recovering from anaesthetic and pain. Now waiting for results... I am hoping they will surprise, but as my Onc says he pretty much is sure it is lung mets, still good to know so then can look ahead to a plan.. Thanks for all your support, it really brightened my day to log in and see replies. THANKS!! Joanne

Posts.Title: Scans Mar 25 & Mar 31 jonimb 30something

Posts.Content: 30something wrote: For those that are still in the child bearing age, ie 20s, 30s.... What have you been advised since being diagnosed with mets, about getting pregnant?  I know most Oncs would be concerned about it and urge against it, I am just curious what others have been told. My Onc says don't throw the hope out the door just yet, (I have small mets on lungs diagnosed March that are being currently closely monitored at present). He is an optimist. I don't have kids, was planning to when rediagnosed (that was why I had a scan only for cancer to show), it was a blow and the candle of hope is still burning....  I am , 35 yrs old...... Anyone know of anyone who went onto have kids after a mets diagnosis? (planned or unplanned)Any words of wisdom? I tell myself it is ok to have hope, miracles happen... and well I guess in time my hope might fade, grief... Thanks Log in to post a reply
